markdownRemark.html:
this and Typescript

  • make tsconfig.json as below - 
    {
  "compilerOptions": {
    "target": "ES5",
    "module": "CommonJS",
    "lib": ["DOM", "ES6"]
  }
}
  • now, the following code won’t give error. however, if we hover over this inside handleClick, it shows any 
    const link = document.querySelector(".click") as HTMLAnchorElement | null

function handleClick(event: Event) {
  event.preventDefault()
  console.log(this.href)
}

link?.addEventListener("click", handleClick, false)
  • we want to throw an error in such cases. so, we can add the property - "noImplicitThis": true to tsconfig.json. now, the above code would throw an error
  • to fix it, we have to type this. we use the first argument of the function to achieve it 
    function handleClick(this: HTMLAnchorElement, event: Event) {
  ...
}

Type Queries

typeof

  • typeof returns a string like ‘number’, ‘string’, ‘object’ etc in javascript. but typescript adds to this behavior
  • syntax - type X = typeof obj
  • if obj has type Pizza, Pizza gets assigned to X

keyof

  • keyof gives the keys of the object,
  • syntax - type K = keyof T

Example

without typed queries -

const Bill = {
  name: "bill",
  age: 25,
}

function getProperty(a: object, b: string) {
  return a[b]
}

const age = getProperty(Bill, "age") // age is any
const education = getProperty(Bill, "education") // doesn't throw error

using typed queries -

type Person = typeof Bill // type Person = { name: string; age: number; }
type PersonKeys = keyof Person // type PersonKeys = "name" | "age"
type PersonValues = Person[PersonKeys] // type PersonValues = string | number

function getProperty<T, K extends keyof T>(a: T, b: K) {
  return a[b]
}

const age = getProperty(Bill, "age") // age is number
const education = getProperty(Bill, "education") // throws error

note - see how typescript infers generic types as well i.e. we didn’t have to use const age = getProperty<Person, PersonKeys>(Bill, "age");

Mapped Types

  • often when using typescript, i would -
    • manually create unnecessary versions of the same type for different operations
    • make one type and try to use it for different operations, by making its fields optional etc
  • mapped types can help prevent such issues

Readonly

map to a type which makes all properties readonly

interface Person {
  name: string
  age: number
}

const freeze = <T>(obj: T): Readonly<T> => Object.freeze(obj)

const Bill: Person = { name: "bill", age: 21 }
const frozenBill = freeze(Bill)

polyfill for readonly (this is just how Readonly is implemented) -

type MyReadOnly<T> = {
  readonly [K in keyof T]: T[K]
}

Partial

make all properties of the type optional

interface Person {
  name: string
  age: number
}

const updatePerson = (person: Person, updates: Partial<Person>): Person => ({
  ...person,
  ...updates,
})

polyfill for partial -

type MyPartial<T> = {
  [K in keyof T]?: T[K]
}

Required

functions opposite to that of Partial

interface Person {
  name: string
  age: number
  id?: number
}

type DbPerson = Required<Person>

creating polyfill for Required

/*
the below isn't enough, since it preserves the optional nature

type MyRequired<T> = {
  [K in keyof T]: T[K]
}
*/

type MyRequired<T> = {
  [K in keyof T]-?: T[K]
}

doubt: +? will add the optional field, -? will remove it? and does that mean + is present by default?

Pick

create a new type with some properties of the original type

interface Person {
  name: string
  age: number
  city: string
  street: string
}

type Address = Pick<Person, "city" | "street">
// type Address = { city: string; street: string; }

polyfill -

type MyPick<T, K extends keyof T> = {
  [P in K]: T[P]
}

Type Guards

can be used when the type of variable is a union of different types

typeof

function foo(bar: number | string) {
  if (typeof bar === "string") {
    // typescript understands bar is a string
  }
}

instanceof

class Foo {
  bar() {}
}

const foo = new Foo()

console.log(Object.getPrototypeOf(foo) === Foo.prototype) // true
console.log(foo instanceof Foo) // true

User Defined Type Guard

the code below throws error, as typescript doesn’t remember what happened because of the predicate

function determineIfNumber(bar: any): boolean {
  return typeof bar === "number"
}

function foo(bar: number | string) {
  if (determineIfNumber(bar)) {
    console.log(`bar is number, ${bar.toFixed(2)}`)
  } else {
    console.log(`bar is a string, ${bar.toUpperCase()}`)
  }
}

can be changed as -

function determineIfNumber(bar: any): bar is number {
  return typeof bar === "number"
}

Intersection Types

combine properties of two different types

interface A {
  a: string
}

interface B {
  b: string
}

type Obj = A & B

const obj: Obj = { a: "a", b: "b" }

Generics

class List<T> {
  private list: T[] = []

  constructor() {}

  addItem(item: T) {
    this.list.push(item)
  }

  getItem(index: number): T {
    return this.list[index]
  }
}

const list = new List<number>()
list.addItem(1)
console.log(list.getItem(0))

Function Overload

  • suppose we have a reverse function 
    function reverse(val: string | any[]): string | any[] {
  if (typeof val === "string") {
    return val.split("").reverse().join("")
  }
  return val.slice().reverse()
}

const a = reverse("")
const b = reverse([])
  • on hovering over a or b we get that they can be either string or any[]. but we know that if we pass a string, we get back a string and if we pass an array, we get back an array
  • for this, we can use function overloading
  • just above the function, we can declare as follows - 
    function reverse(val: string): string
function reverse(val: any[]): any[]
  • and now, a is recognized as string and b as any[]

ReDeclaring Interface

re declaring interfaces add the properties of each other i.e. effect is like intersection (described above)

interface Person {
  name: string
}

interface Person {
  age: number
}

const p: Person = { name: "bill", age: 2 }

re declaring enums works the same way

Declaration Files

Creating Declaration Files

  • we run npm i lodash but we don’t get any autocomplete, warnings i.e. 
    import * as _ from "lodash"

_.foobar() // no error
  • this is because we have no type definitions
  • we can however, create a file @types/index.d.ts and add the below code - 
    declare module "lodash" {
  export function chunk(collection: any[], size?: number): any[][]
}
  • we are instructing typescript what is allowed and what isn’t

Augmenting Declaration Files

  • lodash already has a type declaration file, can be obtained via installing @types/lodash
  • now we get linting etc. automatically
  • lodash has a method mixin which allows us to create a custom method
  • however, trying to use it will give an error as typescript doesn’t know about it 
    import * as _ from "lodash"

_.mixin({
  log(item: string) {
    console.log(`DEBUG:::${item}`)
  },
})

_.log("here") // Property 'log' does not exist on type 'LoDashStatic'.ts
  • we can handle this by creating our own declaration file, and since re declaring interfaces works like intersection (refer above), we can add the code below in @types/index.d.ts 
    import "lodash"

declare module "lodash" {
  interface LoDashStatic {
    log(item: string): void
  }
}
    and update tsconfig.json with "typeRoots": ["src/@types", "node_modules/@types"]

tsconfig.json

  • include - tsc should work on files with this glob pattern e.g. "include": ["src/**/*.ts"]
  • exclude - tsc should not work on files with this glob pattern e.g. "exclude": ["src/**/*.spec.ts"]
  • outDir - folder in which compiled js files should be emitted
  • extends - specify json file to inherit configuration from
  • noImplicitAny - emit error if type is implicitly any
  • noEmitOnError - don’t compile down to js if ts errors exist
  • source maps - source maps help in mapping transformed outputs to source inputs thus helping debug in the browser. can be done via setting "sourceMap": true and "inlineSources": true
  • target - what es version should the compiled js files be in. shouldn’t be too old to prevent large bundles, not too new or they won’t work in browsers
  • experimentalDecorators, emitDecoratorMetadata - for angular, we need to set them to true
  • lib - an array where we specify what features we use, e.g. without adding dom we can’t use document
  • strict - setting strict as true is the equivalent for adding a lot of other tsconfig options like noImplicitAny, noImplicitThis, etc
  • alwaysStrict - adding the use strict option, done automatically via strict
  • noUnusedParameters, noUnusedLocals etc. can be used to enforce code quality
  • importHelpers - allows importing common functionality like polyfills from tslib instead of defining them in every file. npm i tslib and set importHelpers to true to use this feature, helps in optimizing bundle size
